title: params in middleware not work
Param patch #2617
body:
Tests ran successfully at this point. This basically checks all the scenarios:
1. is it a glob
2. is it a capture
3. is it a param capture

title: URL not matched to route when coming from remote server
Newer path-to-regexp version?
body:
Express 4 uses path-to-regexp@0.1.3.
The latest version would be 1.2.0, see https://github.com/pillarjs/path-to-regexp.
How about upgrading to the newer version?

title: Inconsistent router behavior
body:
Fixes an inconsistency within the router:

``` coffeescript
express = require "express"

app = express()


app.param "num", (req, res, next, value) ->
  if value.match(/[0-9]+/)
    next()
  else
    next("route")


app.param "alpha", (req, res, next, value) ->
  if value.match(/[a-z]+/)
    next()
  else
    next("route")


app.get "/:alpha/:num", (req, res) ->
  # this works for /asd/123
  res.status(200).send("Matched Alpha/Num")


app.get "/:alpha/static", (req, res) ->
  # this works for /asd/static
  res.status(200).send("Matched Alpha/Static")


app.get "/:num/static", (req, res) ->
  # this works for /123/static
  res.status(200).send("Matched Num/Static")


app.get "/:num/:alpha", (req, res) ->
  # but this doesn't work for /123/asd (generic 'no route matched' 404 error)
  res.status(200).send("Matched Num/Alpha")


app.listen 1234, ->
  console.log("Ready")
```

This could probably be fixed by using a param regexp instead of a function. However there are cases when that's not enough, for example if you're trying to get an object from a database and fall back onto another route if you couldn't find said object.

title: Express adding charset to Content-Type
body:
We found that by default Express adds the utf-8 charset by default to the Content-Type string. But does it always make sense? The [W3C spec](http://www.w3.org/International/O-HTTP-charset) says:

> Documents transmitted with HTTP that are of type text, such as text/html, text/plain, etc., can send a charset parameter in the HTTP header to specify the character encoding of the document. 

However, sometimes people use `Content-Type`which are not text based, like `application/...` and in their cases, it probably not blindly add `charset:utf-8`.

title: Resolve paths for views asynchronously
body:
This eliminates the only post-startup synchronous I/O in Express.

In addition, this makes the view.lookup method non-private, intended to be used
by view engines to resolve paths to partials, and, if the View class is
extended, could be used for other resources such as internationalized messages.

title: TypeError: Failed to decode param ''
body:
We have a nodejs app running on Heroku, and sometimes, without warning, all requests on a specific web dyno start to fail with a 400 Bad Request response. In the logs we can see entries like this:

```
TypeError: Failed to decode param '' at decode_param (/app/node_modules/express/lib/router/layer.js:162:15)
```

Restarting the app usually helps, but not always. Any idea what could be wrong?

Our package.json dependencies:

```
"dependencies": {
    "body-parser": "^1.12.2",
    "compression": "^1.4.3",
    "ejs": "~1.0.0",
    "errorhandler": "^1.0.0",
    "express": "~4.12.3",
    "extend": "1.2.1",
    "forever": "^0.14.1",
    "jslint": "^0.3.1",
    "mandrill-api": "^1.0.39",
    "newrelic": "1.17.2",
    "querystring": "^0.2.0",
    "request": "2.29.0",
    "requirejs": "^2.1.16",
    "ws": "^0.4.32"
  },
```

We haven't been able to reproduce or trigger this error in a test environment. Since this error is thrown by `decodeURIComponent`, we thought that we were missing some encoding. But after setting `LANG=en_US.UTF-8` the problem still occurs. We have also tried running the app on a local ubuntu vagrant image after removing all installed locales, but that didn't trigger the problem either.

title: baseUrl not working as described?
How to test if route exists?
Support multiple functions in app.param
body:
#2603

A simple change but it might be useful in some cases where we can write shorter code to reuse middleware in `app.param`

title: separate locals from config values
body: Keeping a separate namespace so that what's sent per-request is separate from long-lived configuration values.

title: Delegate `.VERB(...)` calls to `router.VERB(...)` to avoid duplication
body: In the [comment](https://github.com/strongloop/express/blob/6d43bacb4691f255e8d67a8d074e7a3062c8cd5a/lib/application.js#L455) of `lib/application.js`, it says "Delegate `.VERB(...)` calls to `router.VERB(...)`". However, the current implementation just copies the code from the [router methods](https://github.com/strongloop/express/blob/6d43bacb4691f255e8d67a8d074e7a3062c8cd5a/lib/router/index.js#L497-L498) to [app methods](https://github.com/strongloop/express/blob/6d43bacb4691f255e8d67a8d074e7a3062c8cd5a/lib/application.js#L464-L465). To avoid code duplication (and perhaps a little bit of maintenance burden), I made it a real "delegation".

title: Add support for a four-arg view engine
body: It gets a reference to the view object itself, so that the view object can provide services (like lookup) for partials and be configured by Express.

title: Adding query params to route declaration
body:
There's a feature I really like in angular ui-router library, routes allow to define their possible query params ([see ui-router docs](https://github.com/angular-ui/ui-router/wiki/URL-Routing#query-parameters))

For ui-router, it is a feature (they don't take the data unless it's there in the route declaration)

What I really like about it is that it makes the routes more self-documenting, just by glancing at the route you can see which query arguments it uses.

So I'm suggesting two things:
1. "strict query mode" where only the specified query params get taken into `req.query`
2. otherwise allow `/route?var&var5` declaration for the sake of self-documenting the query params

Thoughts? Will this break anything? Can you even use question marks in routes at the moment? I'm guessing that if you can use question marks today this idea is out of the question.

Thanks

title: app.param() does not accept regular expressions as documentation shows
body:
From: http://expressjs.com/4x/api.html#app.param

``` js
app.param('range', /^(\w+)\.\.(\w+)?$/);
```

This does not work as the param method checks if the "fn" parameter sent to it is a function, and it is not.

Regex appear as objects, not functions, and hence express throws an error as shown:

```
express/lib/router/index.js:112
    throw new Error('invalid param() call for ' + name + ', got ' + fn);
          ^
Error: invalid param() call for range, got /^(\w+)\.\.(\w+)?$/
    at Function.param (...... /node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:112:11)
```

title: req.param(id, regexp) doesn't work
4.x performance issue
body:
i was tested 3.x and 4.x  by same get request

```
GET '/health'  -> response 'ok'
```

test result 3.x  is winner about 15% better than 4.x

i guess maybe because route logic

in 3.X

```
console.log(app._router.map)
{ get: 
   [ { path: '/health',
       method: 'get',
       callbacks: [Object],
       keys: [],
       regexp: /^\/health\/?$/i } ],
  post: 
   {}  }
```

in 4.X

```
console.log(app._router.stack)
[ { handle: [Function: query],
    name: 'query',
    params: undefined,
    path: undefined,
    keys: [],
    regexp: { /^\/?(?=\/|$)/i fast_slash: true },
    route: undefined },
  { handle: [Function: expressInit],
    name: 'expressInit',
    params: undefined,
    path: undefined,
    keys: [],
    regexp: { /^\/?(?=\/|$)/i fast_slash: true },
    route: undefined },  
  { handle: [Function],
    name: '<anonymous>',
    params: undefined,
    path: undefined,
    keys: [],
    regexp: /^\/health\/?$/i,
    route: { path: '/health', stack: [Object], methods: [Object] } } ]
```

if my guess is true, how to overcome this performance issue?

title: Optionally account for extra wildcard groups, fixing #2617
body:
Failing test cases for #2617 and optional support for future index value in path-to-regexp from https://github.com/pillarjs/path-to-regexp/pull/51

The issue is that wildcard *'s result in extra capture groups in the regexp, which is expected, however the keys array doesn't account for this at all. The result is that if you have a \* wildcard before any :named parameters then their values will be flip-flopped.

At first I tried making path-to-regexp return the wildcard groups in the keys array, however it resulted in deadlocking the testcase without any errors, so I deemed it too API breaking. Instead I added an "index" value to the keys which correlates to the index in the array of matches.

title: Stop taking new requests?
body:
The official node docs suggest using [domains](https://nodejs.org/api/domain.html) as a way to handle unexpected errors, and the recommended way to deal with such errors is to shut down the process and reboot it again. Specifically, they stop taking all new requests with `server.close();` and kill the process with `process.exit(1);` in the domain.

What is the equivalent of `server.close()` in Express? I thought it might have been `app.close()`, but I get an error saying `has no method 'close'`.

return values of next()
Complete test description
body: The description for this test was missing

title: Will express support generator or async function as request handler so there will be no callback ?
body: Like koa

title: this vs self in response.js
body:
Is there a reason that `this` is used rather than assigning `this` to `self`?

I was using it like follows:

``` js
var send = _.compose(res.send, withMessageAs)
```

but it should be:

``` js
var send = _.compose(res.send.bind(res), withMessageAs)
```

I was a bit surprised to find that `self` wasn't used. Is there a reason behind that? Is there ever an instance where it would be desirable to use `this`?

title: Allow named parameters is regexp routes.
Use mime-types instead of mime
body:
One of the [changes for Release 5.0](https://github.com/strongloop/express/pull/2237) is

> Use mime-types instead of mime

I thought I'll have a crack at it, so I replaced mime with [mime-types](https://www.npmjs.com/package/mime-types)

mime-types will return the mime-type with charset for example `"application/javascript; charset=utf-8`

Is this what's expected or should it **not** send through the charset?

title: Hot reload
body:
I think that it's good if express supports hot reload when runs in debug-mode.
Also, awesome if we can config the hot-reload module.

title: Container elements not properly rendered inside of SVG elements
body:
I'm not sure if this is an issue with ExpressJS or Jade, but the typical HTML container elements (div and span come to mind) that supposedly work in SVG elements too are rendered outside of the SVG element. 

An example like the following would cause the div to get rendered outside the SVG element. Note : I have tried adding all the gobbledy gook that you would normally add if it was an SVG file. It didn't change a thing. I tried doing height/width with and without quotes, with and without pixels. I tried putting everything inside of style="". It still renders the div outside of the SVG element. 

```
  svg#testing
    defs
      pattern#flowers(patternUnits="userSpaceOnUse" width=276 height=183)
        image(xlink:href='/img/flowers.jpg', height=183 width=276)
    div
      circle#circle(cx=50 cy=50 r=10 fill='url(#flowers)')
```

title: utils: use external pathIsAbsolute
body: @dougwilson thoughts? I removed the tests since it does per-platform checking.

title: change res.links() to also accept array
Best way to simulate a request internally?
req.params not in correct order when use a * before
Add .npmignore to exclude development files from the npm package
body: I copied .gitignore as .npmignore and added a few development files and folders to be excluded from the npm package as they're unnecessary. Also removed node_modules as it's unnecessary as per npm's [documentation](https://docs.npmjs.com/misc/developers).

title: Added Route.prototype.verbs
body:
This method allows to register a set of verbs in just one call and allows to define a default route for all the Others.

This is different from using all, because the default route is added only to the verbs for which there is not a defined one.

title: IPv4/v6 problems trying to connect to the server
body:
Hey all,

I'm not 100% sure if it could be an express problem or just an error in my network configuration, I hope someone could give me a hand understanding this error.

I'm using this simple code to create a server:

``` js
'use strict';

var express = require('express');

var PORT = 8080,
  SERVER = 'http://localhost:' + PORT;

var app = express(),
  server;

app.get('/', function(req, res) {
  res.sendStatus(200);
});
```

In the terminal, I'm running the following commands:

> $ curl -v http://localhost:8080/
> * Hostname was NOT found in DNS cache
> *   Trying ::1...
> * connect to ::1 port 8080 failed: Connection refused
> *   Trying fe80::1...
> * connect to fe80::1 port 8080 failed: Connection refused
> * Failed to connect to localhost port 8080: Connection refused
> * Closing connection 0
> curl: (7) Failed to connect to localhost port 8080: Connection refused

but:

> $ curl -v http://127.0.0.1:8080/
> * Hostname was NOT found in DNS cache
> *   Trying 127.0.0.1...
> * Connected to 127.0.0.1 (127.0.0.1) port 8080 (#0)
> > GET / HTTP/1.1
> > User-Agent: curl/7.37.1
> > Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
> > Accept: _/_
> > 
> < HTTP/1.1 200 OK
> < X-Powered-By: Express
> < Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
> < Content-Length: 2
> < ETag: W/"2-d736d92d"
> < Date: Fri, 03 Apr 2015 21:16:30 GMT
> < Connection: keep-alive
> < 
> * Connection #0 to host 127.0.0.1 left intact

I'm using node@0.10.35, express@4.12.3, running on OSX 10.10.2 (14C109).

Any ideas?

I'll really appreciate any help.

title: QUESTION: Why is obj.__proto__=... being used instead of calling Object.create
body:
In the ./lib/express.js & in the ./lib/router/index.js (and probably more places) the `__proto__` is being set directly either in the form `obj.__proto__ =` ... or in the form  `obj = { __proto__: ... }`

Mozilla does not recommend this:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Object/proto

they say it will heavily impact performance in modern javascript engines... I am not sure how relevant this is to vp8 engine, but Mozilla suggests using `Object.create` instead.

Is there a reason why you opted no to use `Object.create`?

Just very curious about this decision.

Thank you

response.js: use statusCodes short cut instead of http.STATUS_CODES
body:
At the top of the file there is a short cut for http.STATUS_CODES:

  var statusCodes = http.STATUS_CODES;

A couple of places in the module still referenced http.STATUS_CODES
directly. Replace those references with the short cut, statusCodes.

title: Convert router stack to an object of arrays
Change express.logger in route-separation example
body:
In the route-separation example, morgan had been included in index.js and assigned to variable 'logger'. However, express.logger was used instead of the variable assigned to morgan. This generated the following error in Express 4: 

```
Error: Most middleware (like logger) is no longer bundled with Express and must be installed separately. Please see https://github.com/senchalabs/connect#middleware.
    at Function.Object.defineProperty.get (/Users/alexdixon/express/lib/express.js:89:13)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/alexdixon/express/examples/route-separation/index.js:24:19)
```

express.logger has been replaced with the existing variable for morgan. The example can now be run in the current version of the app.

title: Add isset() to express?
body:
In PHP you can do  
`if( isset($var) ) { ... }`

In JavaScript you often use 
`if( typeof var != 'undefined' ) { ... }`
for similar functionality.  

It would be great to have this functionality built into express by default, to clean up the code a little bit.   

What do you guys think?

title: Removing routes at runtime
body:
First off, let me say that I'm an Express beginner and so far I'm very impressed with what it can do.
I set up my node.js application to watch file changes and those file changes actually can incur the need to alter routes. Therefore I searched the [routing documentation](http://expressjs.com/guide/routing.html) and it seems there is no official, documented way to do it.

I quickly searched if this issue already existed on GitHub but I couldn't find it via "remove" or "remove routes".

A few minutes of Google-fu later it seems there are some ways to do it:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/15027514/node-js-remove-route-while-server-is-running
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10378690/remove-route-mappings-in-nodejs-express

However those don't seem to be well documented and I don't see why Express shouldn't have an officially documented function à la "app.remove()" or a similar mechanism to remove routes.

If there is something I missed please let me know.

I've seen some attempts but was looking for your advice on a best way to do that.

title: Bug at express.js line 5, "EventEmitter" requirement
body:
Im having a error message when i try to use the express-generator via `express <my_app_name>` and this is sending me to the line 5 of the express.js file in the lib folder:

express/lib/express.js line 5:

`var EventEmitter = require('events').EventEmitter;`

Is someone having this error message either? Can we do something to fix it?
If this affects me and I dont know how many people called `x`, we are having `x` persons that cannot use the express generator to make an app.
Thanks for your time of reading and I dont have the intention to make spam or something. Im creating this issue as a way of help and contribuite to express reporting the problem.

title: app.all does NOT accept _any_ HTTP Method
body:
the docs seem to indicate that `app.all` will accept ANY HTTP Method ... that is simply untrue, i'm not sure why, I plan to dive into the code and inspect, but starting with a ticket here first.

``` js
var express = require('../');
var app = express();

app.all('/test', function(req, res){
  res.end(req.method);
});

app.listen(8888);
```

``` shell
$ curl -X TEST localhost:8888/test
curl: (52) Empty reply from server
```

``` shell
$ curl -X TEST localhost:8888/test -v
* Hostname was NOT found in DNS cache
*   Trying 127.0.0.1...
* Connected to localhost (127.0.0.1) port 8888 (#0)
> TEST /test HTTP/1.1
> User-Agent: curl/7.35.0
> Host: localhost:8888
> Accept: */*
> 
* Empty reply from server
* Connection #0 to host localhost left intact
curl: (52) Empty reply from server
```

title: 'range' router.param rule in the doc does not work
body:
The doc says, in the `Router` section, that the following rule:

``` javascript
router.get(‘/range/:range(\w+..\w+)’, function(req, res) {
router.get('/range/:range(\\w+\.\.\\w+)', function(req, res, next) { }
```

should match: "should start with one more alphanumeric characters, followed by two dots, and end with one more alphanumeric characters".

But it just does not work. It should be:

``` javascript
router.get('/range/:range(\\w+\.\.\\w+)', function(req, res, next) { }
```

(as in the `app.param` section).

title: Gzip compression not working from 3.18.0 to 3.20.1
body:
Hi!

I want to update Express in my node app. But I decided to stay on 3.x line.
After some tests I realized, that gzip compression module not working in my app after express@3.18.0 (3.17.8 works nice).

When gzip is on, I got this error, just after sending response:

```
Error in application:
TypeError: string is not a function
at zlib.js:353:13
at Zlib.callback (zlib.js:446:13)
```

I'm using this code to turn compress on:

``` js
app.use(express.compress({
    filter : function (req, res, next) {
      return /json|text|javascript|css/.test(res.getHeader('Content-Type'));
    },
    level : 9
  }));
```

Node version: v0.8.26

Any ideas? Thx!

title: Document usage of path-to-regexp
body:
In the routing and api references, it would be useful to link to the path-to-regexp project for further information on what can be done in the paths. It seems like those documents are written assuming that the reader knows what's happening behind the scenes. It might be useful to link to the [Express routing tester](http://forbeslindesay.github.io/express-route-tester/) as well.

Specifically, I was trying to find information about how to specify matching rules for a named parameter like  `/account/:accound_id(\\d+)` and only found examples that _used_ the format (in a note defining a workaround for a deprecated function), but nothing that explicitly defined that such a format was perfectly acceptable. Once I dove into the code and found path-to-regexp, it all became clear.

title: Windows: cannot use absolut path in layout-option of response.render
hooking into the server closing?
body: If I hit "ctrl-c" or "cmd-c" in a terminal that's running an express server, the server gets kill off, but is there a way to hook into the server's close event, so that cleanup can be run before the script is killed?

title: Post route not found!
req.params is empty in error handler
Support rejected promises
links() function insufficient for attributes other than `rel`
skeleton app results in a 500 internal server Error
body:
`doctype 5` is deprecated, you must now use `doctype html`

To fix, replace `doctype 5` by `doctype html` in first line of generated views/layout.jade

Regards

title: Documentation for middleware parameter count
body:
In the past few days, I've seen two instances of #Node.js IRC users running into trouble with middleware parameters, where the parameters would not contain the expected data.

In both cases, the issue was a piece of middleware with the signature `(err, req, res)`. Due to the parameter count, Express seemingly assumes that the signature is `(req, res, next)` and thus treats the middleware as regular middleware. It is evidently not obvious to users that the middleware type is determined by the parameter count, and that they cannot simply omit the `next` parameter for error handling middleware.

I'm not sure of the specific place it would fit in, but this should probably be in the documentation somewhere, to keep people from running into this trap :)

title: Fix for req.protocol when set('trust proxies', n) is used
body: Fix for #2569

title: .set('trust proxy', 3) doesn't work as documented. Will never trust proxies even if `hops` is specified.
body:
I'm pretty certain that the `.set('trust proxy', 2)` style will not work as documented. `trust(address, hops)` is expected by https://github.com/strongloop/express/blob/master/lib/utils.js#L249

Most likely this should be something like `if (!trust(this.connection.remoteAddress, proxyaddr.all(this, trust).length))`

https://github.com/strongloop/express/commit/566720be15838f3fe9b30263a7058a8b497c28f5#diff-96d9811cb2296e877edf463c6cfc57bdR353

title: Getting Route handler callback to work with together with middleware
Static middleware example throw TypeError: Arguments to path.join must be strings - v10 / v12 on OSX Maverick
body:
Hi there, trying to run a static server with express 4 latest (4.12.0). Here is the example : 

``` js
var express = require('express'),
  app = express(),
  port = 8100,
  options = {
    dotfiles: 'ignore',
    etag: false,
    extensions: ['htm', 'html'],
    index: true,
    maxAge: '1d',
    redirect: false,
    setHeaders: function(res, path, stat) {
      res.set('x-timestamp', Date.now())
    }
  };
app.use(express.static('www', options));
app.listen(port);
```

This example is from the docs : http://expressjs.com/guide/using-middleware.html#middleware.built-in

node version : 
`v0.10.35` and `v0.12.0`

Folder structure : 

```
-- test/
---- serve.js
---- www/
------- index.html
```

Nothing else is running, I was expecting to see a hello world index.html page.

Here is the stack : 

```
TypeError: Arguments to path.join must be strings
   at path.js:360:15
   at Array.filter (native)
   at exports.join (path.js:358:36)
   at next (/Volumes/Macintosh HD/Users/gabrielstuff/Sources/node/playground/node_modules/express/node_modules/send/index.js:638:13)
   at SendStream.sendIndex (/Volumes/Macintosh HD/Users/gabrielstuff/Sources/node/playground/node_modules/express/node_modules/send/index.js:649:3)
   at SendStream.pipe (/Volumes/Macintosh HD/Users/gabrielstuff/Sources/node/playground/node_modules/express/node_modules/send/index.js:475:10)
   at serveStatic (/Volumes/Macintosh HD/Users/gabrielstuff/Sources/node/playground/node_modules/express/node_modules/serve-static/index.js:111:12)
   at Layer.handle [as handle_request] (/Volumes/Macintosh HD/Users/gabrielstuff/Sources/node/playground/node_modules/express/lib/router/layer.js:82:5)
   at trim_prefix (/Volumes/Macintosh HD/Users/gabrielstuff/Sources/node/playground/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:302:13)
   at /Volumes/Macintosh HD/Users/gabrielstuff/Sources/node/playground/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:270:7
```

Thanks,

title: Is there a way to register a function/layer after the app.get function
body: I want to do the cleanup thing after each get or post route is done, since `route.use` is called before the `route.$httpmethod`, so I wonder is there a way to register a function which is called **_after**_ the `route.$httpmethod`.

title: query param number values from client request turn into strings in req.query
body:
I'm not sure if this is due to the nature of http or something express is doing, but I am passing numbers as values to my express api and when I try to obtain them with req.query.x they are typeof string. This is causing me to do extra manual work on the server as my db is expecting numbers. If numbers remained type number, I could just pass them to my db outright through my blueprint and not have to do a custom controller.

Please advise.

title: Shouldn't app.set("case sensitive routing") propagate to new Routers?
body:
Just wondering if app settings such as "case sensitive routing" should be also applied in new `Router` instances created by the user.

Of course that would require some kind of magic in what `express.Router` returns (it should be a function that creates a new `Router` and applies the app settings unless provided by the user).

title: Simplify app.all and app.VERB
Application may be a class
`Cannot redefine property: name` in createApplication since v4.10
body:
Issue happens in v4.10 and v4.12 but not in v4.9.8

it can be reproduced easily using a coffee repl:

```
coffee> (require 'events').EventEmitter.prototype.name = "letscrashthis"
coffee> (require 'express')()
```

In my case, I ran into this issue because `require('events').EventEmitter.prototype.name`'s value at runtime before executing `require('express')()` is "EventEmitter" as a read-only property.

 In `createApplication()`, the line `mixin(app, EventEmitter.prototype);` causes the following error: 

```
TypeError: Cannot redefine property: name
  at Function.defineProperty (native)
  at ./node_modules/express/node_modules/merge-descriptors/index.js:4:12
  at Array.forEach (native)
  at module.exports (./node_modules/express/node_modules/merge-descriptors/index.js:2:35)
  at createApplication (./node_modules/express/lib/express.js:35:3)
```

I am still investigating what is defining EventEmitter.prototype.name and will send more info when I find something
